stem: A 4-year-old child presents at 1400 with extreme weight gain (+5 lbs in one week), tight-fitting clothes, and frothy-appearing urine. Labs show massive proteinuria and 2.0 g/dL serum albumin. Complete the bowtie to guide care.

actions.text: Initiate a high-salt diet to improve osmotic pressure
Place the child in a shared room with a child who has pneumonia

parameters.text: Skin integrity especially in edematous areas

rationale.correct: Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The pathophysiology involves damage to the glomerular podocytes, leading to increased permeability and massive proteinuria. This protein loss results in hypoalbuminemia, decreased oncotic pressure, and subsequent edema. Administering corticosteroids, like Prednisone, is the first-line treatment as it helps to reduce glomerular permeability and decrease protein excretion. Daily urine protein testing monitors the effectiveness of treatment. Monitoring abdominal circumference and daily weights helps assess fluid retention. Edematous skin is prone to breakdown, requiring vigilant skin care.
rationale.incorrect: A high-salt diet exacerbates edema by increasing fluid retention. Placing an immunocompromised child (due to steroid use) in a room with a child with pneumonia increases the risk of infection. While blood pressure monitoring is important, it is not the priority in MCD as hypertension is less common than in other glomerular diseases. Serum glucose is not directly related to the pathophysiology of MCD.
clinicalPearls: Instruct parents on proper urine dipstick technique for home protein monitoring. Emphasize the importance of completing the full course of corticosteroids, even if symptoms improve. Teach parents about potential side effects of corticosteroids, such as increased appetite and mood changes.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that sodium restriction is crucial during the edematous phase to minimize fluid retention. Avoid high-sodium foods and educate the family on reading food labels.

This results in hypoalbuminemia, decreased oncotic pressure, and edema. Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment. Monitor fluid status and skin integrity.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Minimal Change Disease
reviewUnits.body: Administer corticosteroids, monitor urine protein, assess fluid status (abdominal circumference, daily weights), and provide meticulous skin care. Avoid high-salt diets and protect the child from infection.
